results.title: W.A. Mozart
results.creator_credit: Jeremy Marre, John Seabourne and Seabourne Enterprises
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Great composers”
The life and work of Mozart is discussed and excerpts from his music are interspersed throughout the film. This film features the London Mozart Players and Russian pianist, Nina Milkina. Introduction by Nina Milkina.

results.title: W. Somerset Maugham's Trio
results.creator_credit: Harold French, Ken Annakin, Antony Darnborough and Two Cities Films
results.brief_description: ‘Trio’ forms the second of three movie anthologies based on the short stories of British author W. Somerset Maugham. Other titles in the anthology include ‘Quartet’ (303249), and ‘Encore’ (309327). Stories include: ‘The Verger’; a verger’s fortunes change when he is dismissed by the Bishop: ‘Mr Knowall’ (Nigel Patrick), is an excruciating and over enthusiastic individual who bores his fellow passengers during a voyage, and: ‘Sanitorium’; Jean Simmons, Michael Rennie and Roland Culver star as tuberculosis patients who find some happiness despite their condition. Cast includes James Hayter, Kathleen Harrison and Felix Alymer. Introduced by Somerset Maugham.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Harold French, Ken Annakin, Antony Darnborough and Two Cities Films

results.title: W. Somerset Maugham's Encore
results.creator_credit: Anthony Pelissier, Harold French, Pat Jackson, Antony Darnborough and Two Cities Films
results.brief_description: ‘Encore’ forms the final instalment of three movie anthologies based on the short stories of British author W. Somerset Maugham. Other titles in the anthology include ‘Quartet’ (303249), and ‘Trio’ (309324). Stories include: ‘The Ant and the grasshopper’; brothers Tom and George Ramsay (Nigel Patrick and Roland Culver), attempt to outdo each other over money; ‘Winter cruise’; grouchy matron Miss Read is in danger of ruining a cruise, and; ‘Gigolo and Gogolette’; poised to perform her most death defying act, trapeze artist Glynis Johns suffers a panic attack when she suspects her husband and manager are conspiring to abuse her. Cast includes Nigel Patrick, Roland Culver, Kay Walsh and Noel Purcell. Introduced by Somerset Maugham.

results.title: VTR St-Jacques
results.creator_credit: Bonnie Sherr Klein, George C. Stoney and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: An experiment in using videotape recording (VTR) and closed-circuit television to stimulate social action in a poor district of Montreal. A citizens’ committee, formed in the downtown neighborhood of St-Jacques, was given a VTR unit, which they used to record people’s problems and concerns. After viewing the edited tapes, people recognized their common problems and began to talk of joint solutions. In trying to change what needed changing they ran into resistance, but the effectiveness of this means of promoting joint action had been tested and proved. In English and French with English subtitles.

results.title: Vronsky and Babin. Part two
results.creator_credit: S.K. Winston, Walter Lowendahl and Artists Films
results.brief_description: Part two of a two-part series. The internationally famous duo-pianists, Vitya Vronsky and Victor Babin, play the Polovitizian Dances, from Borodin’s opera “Prince Igor”. In this film the pianos are placed side by side so that both keyboards may be observed at the same time.

results.title: Vronsky and Babin. Part one
results.creator_credit: S.K. Winston, Walter Lowendahl and Artists Films
results.brief_description: Part one of a two-part series. The internationally famous duo-pianists, Vitya Vronsky and Victor Babin, play “Waltz in A Flat” by Brahms; “Waltz” by Arensky; and “Flight of the Bumble Bee” by Rimsky-Korsakoff.

results.title: Voyage to Melonia: a fantasy based on Shakespeare's play "The Tempest"
results.brief_description: Loosely based on Shakespeare’s play “The Tempest” this delightful animated film from Sweden tells the story of young Ferdinand’s escape from slavery on the island of Plutonia to the magical island of Melonia. On Melonia he meets Miranda, her father Prospero, Hobb, a friendly spirit and the ever-complaining gardener, Caliban. With their help he returns to Plutonia to rescue his fellow slaves and defeat the island’s evil rulers Muck and Myer.
results.title_for_label: Voyage to Melonia: a fantasy based on Shakespeare’s play “The Tempest”

results.title: Voyage to Italy = Viaggio in Italia
results.creator_credit: Roberto Rossellini, Marcello D'Amico, Italia Film and Speva Films
results.brief_description: Voyage to Italy marked Rosellini’s break with the aesthetics of neo-realism. Ingrid Bergman and George Sanders play a bored English couple who realise their marriage is falling apart while on a working holiday in Italy. The film is structured as a series of seemingly random scenes in which the disintegration of the marriage is viewed through the relationship between the characters and their external world. This deliberately “clinical” mise-en-scene outraged critics on the film’s initial release. However for a new generation of film-makers Rosellini’s work in “Voyage to Italy” marked the beginning of an intellectual cinema dedicated to examining the existential condition of modern Europe.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Roberto Rossellini, Marcello D’Amico, Italia Film and Speva Films

results.title: Voyage En Grande Tartarie = Trip Through Purgatory
results.brief_description:
Unhinged by the murder of his wife by a madman dressed as a cowboy, Alexis hops into his car and lays himself wide open for a number of adventures; some of them are heavenly, but most of them are harrowing in the extreme. Along the way he meets a suicidal emigre and brings her along his complicated journey.

Credits: Producer, Marin Karmitz ; director, Jean-Charles Tacchella ; writer, Jean-Charles Tacchella ; photography, Andre Dubreuil ; music, Gerard Anfosso.
Cast: Jean-Luc Bideau, Micheline Lanctot, Lou Castel, Catherine Verlor, Catherine Laborde.

results.title: Voyage a travers l'impossible
results.brief_description: Across mountains, under the sea and into the sun, a group of strange travellers attempt an impossible voyage. Exploiting Melies’ mastery of film magic, this early cinema classic explores a vast range of fantasy landscapes. The travellers breach space and time as they travel, using every imaginable means of transportation, from one space and place to another in the attempt to geographically explore the earth and the surrounding space. This extraordinary science fiction fantasy was only one of the many pioneering films made by Melies in the early 1900s and it, like his other films, combines whimsical humour with wild imaginative journeys.
